prompts.prompt: Keep a dream journal. Write down what you dreamt of first thing every morning.
Keep a food journal. Describe your favourite thing that you’ve eaten each day. What did it taste/smell/feel like?
Keep a weather journal. Describe the weather every day in as much detail as you can.
Keep a minor annoyances journal. Describe one thing that bugged you.
Keep a sky journal. Spend five minutes every day looking at the sky and describe it in as much detail as you can.
Keep a reading journal. Take note of your favourite thing (it might only be a word or a sentence) you read every day.
Keep a song journal. What songs did you listen to? See if there are any patterns. Did you listen to the same song every day? Is there a particular time of day you like to listen to songs?
Keep a coincidence journal. Note any weird coincidences that you spot.
Keep a room journal. Describe all the rooms you spent time in today. What do they look/sound/ feel/ smell like?
Write a list poem of things you hate.
Write a love poem to the moon.
Keep a lunch journal. Write down what you have for lunch every day. Describe it in as much detail as you can (smell/ taste/ texture) and give your opinion.
Keep a walking journal. Go for a walk every day and describe one thing you see.
Write a list poem of things you love.
Keep an ideas journal. Note the weirdest, funniest or most comforting idea that pops into your head every day.
Write a poem beginning 'I remember...'
Keep a round things journal. Make note of every round object you see in a day.
Keep a square things journal. Make note of every square object you see in a day.
Keep a soft things journal. Make note of every soft object you see in a day.
Wish poem: write a poem beginning ‘I wish…’
Comparison poem: write a poem comparing two things.
Love poem to an object: write a poem telling an object how much you love it and why.
Song poem: listen to your favourite song; write down the words that pop into your head while listening; put them in a poem.
Found poem: pick up a book; open it on page 76; choose any 10 words; put them in a poem.
Dream poem: write a poem beginning ‘Last night I dreamt…’
Love poem to a pet: write a poem to your pet, telling them why you love them.
Kitchen machine poem: go into your kitchen; find a useful appliance or gadget there; write a poem telling it how it makes your life better.
Furniture poem: write a love poem to your favourite item of furniture.
Newspaper poem: take a random line from a newspaper article and use it as the first line of your poem.
Total rhyme: write a poem about anything where all the lines rhyme (use rhymezone to help you find good rhyming words).
Internal rhyme poem: write a poem about anything where each line has an internal rhyme (use rhymezone to help you find good rhyming words).
Write a poem that doesn’t use the word ‘the.’
Write a poem with no adjectives.
Simile poem: write a poem with a simile in every line.
Metaphor poem: write a poem with a metaphor in every line.
Find a poem you like. Remove all the verbs and replace them with new ones.
Find a poem you like. Remove all the nouns and replace them with new ones.
Write a poem in rhyming couplets.
Write a poem that describes an object in your house. Don’t name the object or give the poem a title. Give the poem to someone to read and see if they can guess the object.
Write a poem that describes your favourite song. Don’t name the song or give the poem a title. Give the poem to someone to read and see if they can guess the song.
Write a poem that describes your favourite food. Don’t name the food or give the poem a title. Give the poem to someone to read and see if they can guess the food.
Write a poem about yourself without using the word ‘I’.
Take a line from your favourite poem and use it as the first line of a poem of your own.
Take a line from your favourite story and use it as the first line of a poem of your own.
Take a line from a nursery rhyme and use it as the first line of a poem of your own.
Take a line from your favourite song and use it as the first line of a poem of your own.
Take a line from your science textbook and use it as the first line of a poem of your own.
Take a line from your geography textbook and use it as the first line of a poem of your own.
Take a line from your history textbook and use it as the first line of a poem of your own.
Write a Shakespearean sonnet (a 14-line poem with the rhyme scheme abab cdcd efef gg)
Write a quatrain (4-line poem) with the rhyme scheme abab.
Write a Limerick (a 5-line poem with the rhyme scheme aabba)
Write a haiku (a 3-line poem with 5 syllables in the 1st line, 7 syllables in the 2nd line and 5 syllables in the 3rd line). It should refer to something in the natural world.
Write a haiku (a 3-line poem with 5 syllables in the 1st line, 7 syllables in the 2nd line and 5 syllables in the 3rd line) about Spring.
Write a haiku (a 3-line poem with 5 syllables in the 1st line, 7 syllables in the 2nd line and 5 syllables in the 3rd line) about bees.
Write a haiku (a 3-line poem with 5 syllables in the 1st line, 7 syllables in the 2nd line and 5 syllables in the 3rd line) about your pet.
Write a haiku (a 3-line poem with 5 syllables in the 1st line, 7 syllables in the 2nd line and 5 syllables in the 3rd line) about cheese.
Write a haiku (a 3-line poem with 5 syllables in the 1st line, 7 syllables in the 2nd line and 5 syllables in the 3rd line) about grass.
Write a haiku (a 3-line poem with 5 syllables in the 1st line, 7 syllables in the 2nd line and 5 syllables in the 3rd line) about your garden.
Write a story in which all the characters have the same name.
Write a story about a scientist whose invention changes the world.
Rewrite the story of ‘Little Red Riding Hood’ from the wolf’s point of view.
Rewrite the story of ‘The Three Little Pigs’ from the wolf’s point of view.
Rewrite ‘Cinderella’ from the point of view of one of the ugly sisters.
Write a new chapter for your favourite book. It can come before, after or during the story.
Choose a minor character from a book who you feel doesn’t get enough attention and write a story where they are the central character.
Choose a story whose ending left you unsatisfied and rewrite the ending.
Describe the setting for the opening scene of a horror story.
Describe the setting for the opening scene of a ghost story.
Describe the setting for the opening scene of a love story.
Describe the setting for the opening scene of a detective story.
Invent and describe a new superhero.
Invent and describe the characters for a new TV sitcom
Write a ghost story in five paragraphs.
Write a love story in five paragraphs.
Write a detective story in five paragraphs.
Write a horror story in five paragraphs.
Invent and describe a new animal.
Describe a day in the life of a jungle animal.
Describe a day in the life of a farm animal.
Describe a day in the life of a pet.
Describe a day in the life of a sea creature.
Write the story of how a common household object was invented.
Write the story of how people discovered how to write.
Write the story of how people discovered how to sing.
Write the story of how people discovered how to bake bread.
Write the story of how people discovered how to make clothes.
Write the story of how people discovered how to draw.
Write the story of how people discovered how to grow crops.
Write the story of how people discovered how to catch fish.
Write the story of how people discovered how to swim.
Write a speech to persuade your classmates that school should be optional.
Write a speech to present your latest invention to the world.
Write a speech to persuade your classmates of the value of reading.
Write a speech to persuade your classmates of the importance of music.
Write a speech made entirely of questions.
Write a speech made entirely of language you’ve found on the internet.
Write a speech made entirely of song lyrics.
Write a speech to persuade the minister for education to change the school system.
Write a speech to encourage your classmates to do random acts of kindness.
Write a speech for your classmates on the wonders of technology.
Write a speech for your classmates on the importance of quiet time on your own.
